div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: RAILWAYS IN SYRIA
div.p: The problem of the railway systems of Northern Syria has lately entered a new phase, and its proposed solution has taken a direction hither to thought very improbable. Before discussing this problem the history of the said railways and the facts of the actual position should be briefly reviewed. The French Société Economique, the original concessionnaire, started by building a narrow cogwheel line from Beyrout to Damascus and thence to Mezerib, which by a fatal error in the survey manifested in the abnormally steep gradients along that part that crosses the Lebanon, did not and could not pay. Therefore the said company had to ask the Regie Générale to build for it the Rayak-Homs-Hama broad gauge line and finally the further extension to Aleppo. One of the principal motives of these later enterprises was to feed the narrow line. In fact the Rayak Aleppo railroad being guaranteed kilometrically by the Turkish Government tho support of the narrow line was, and is, being made at its expense. But the latter with its inherent defects was a stumbling block in the way of the expanding trade, and the transhipment system at Kayak necessitated by the unequal width of the two tracks, aggravated matters. This and the prospect of further progressive development that was calculated to bring out into still stronger relief the hopeless character of the narrow line, led naturally the French Railway Company contemplate the building of a broad railroad with a reasonable inclination to join Beyrout with Kayak and Aleppo, and thus afford a rational means of transport that would cope with the present and future requirements of the trade. Several routes were suggested, but that of Hammana, with the gigantic 5 to 6 kilometres tunnel works it involved, seemed to be thought at one time the only one capable of realisation. This route was actually surveyed the spring, and negotiations were being actively conducted at Constantinople for the obtention of an adequate kilometric guarantee, when the Tripoli Horns project, that had hitherto been floated, came forth in the palpable and serious shape. Although most rational, yet it had always been thought to be beyond the bounds of possibility, through a supposed preemptive right embodied in the French Railways concession. Thanks, however, to the bold initiative and enterprise of a patriotic Moslem Richard of Tripoli, this fiction was dispelled from popular fancy, and not only that, but an old right was discovered in the firman of the Compagnie de Chaussee of Tripoli, for the building of a railway to Homs. The matter having been studied by competent lawyers and found legally sound, a body of leading Tripolitans moved with a solidarity of feeling and interests gathered about a million francs and delegated the Richard to Constantinople to obtain the Imperial Trade. Judging by recent rumors the negotiations are said to have reached such a mature stage that a firm offer has been made by a Belgian Company to the would be concessionaire, and it is further stated that the French Railway Company itself has come forward also with an offer for the building of the line. If this be true it would be a precautionary step on their part to minimize a possible disaster. In the opinion of the writer, and all those who have cared to interest themselves in the railways of Syria the Tripoli-Homs scheme although a very rational one per se and enjoying perhaps legal authority will nevertheless run a poor chance of materializing. There are two considerations of capital importance that should prevent this. First the kilometric guarantee and then the question of the Beyrout Harbour and to a certain extent the narrow line, and that part of the broad one between Rayak and Homs. The Tripoli-Homs railway will prove highly prejudicial to all those interest. As it is the French Company finds means of arranging its accounts in such a way as to pay a large part of the expensive upkeep of the narrow cogwheel line out of the kilometric guarantee of the broad Rayak Aleppo extension. Still the Ottoman Government does not pay the full guarantee, whilst with the Tripoli-Homs junction, the Kayak Homs section may receive such a deadly blow that its receipts may be reduced to practically nil and then the Turkish Government may have to bear the constant debt of a full guarantee on that section. So much for the Turkish Government. The loss to the other party viz. the French Society Economique, would be still more serious. The non-guaranteed narrow cogwheel line will relapse into its former state of bankruptcy while the Beyrout harbor which is a dependent concern of the French railway will fall into insolvency through the retrogression of the trade. For once Tripoli is linked to Homs by a railway, and all those vast and fertile regions which will be tapped by it will pour their rich grain produce through the easy and rational route to Tripoli instead of the irrational and awkward one to Beyrout in transshipment to Rayak. So much for exportation. The imports to Homs and Hama and even to Aleppo will also find their way through Tripoli instead of the Rayak-Homs-Hama Line, Tripoli was the natural port of these districts. It will thus be seen that the French Railway Company will do everything in its power and even go to the length of getting the Republic to make a question politique of this new project rather than allow its materialization, and as the Turkish Government has reason to object thereto owing to the guarantee as just explained the task of the French Company will not be very difficult to accomplish.

Some people assert that the Hammana route is so expensive that it can never pay, and that therefore the Tripoli scheme being the only rational and financially feasible one the French railway should decide therein as a bitter pill. But whoever has thoughtfully considered the brilliant idea of Baron Von Kapp, one of the administrators of the said railway, will find that the Hammana scheme, far from bearing an inherent element of bankruptcy, will prove a financial success, strange as this may superficially seem. The Baron conceived the grand idea of making the adjacent bay to the other side of the present harbour another vaster one adapted to the principles and requirements of modern shipping with a large crescent of quays reclaimed from the shallow breach and filled up with the debris of the Hammana tunnel. It has been calculated that the profit realized on the quays and this was based on prices actually obtained by the Port Company on its present quay land - will cover the cost of the tunnel, which is put down at not more than 20 million francs. In this way the problem will be solved satisfactorily without any prejudice to either the Government or the French Railway Company. If the Turkish Government should have to pay a certain guarantee on this new broad junction it will be more than recouped on the strategical side. The whole line from Aleppo to Beirut would then be at its disposal in times of war. This important problem has reached an acute stage and people watch with anxiety the denouement.

div.head: The Christian Brothers Sports
div.p: The annual athletic Sports of the Christian Brothers' Schools at Alexandria will take place on Wednesday next.

div.head: The Plague
div.p: Yesterday's bulletin reports 1 new case of plague at Alexandria and five recoveries ; 1 death at Mallawi ; 1 death at Deirout, and one new case at Damanhour.

div.head: Suez Canal Tug
div.p: Built for the Suez Canal Company, the "Hercules" the largest tug in the world, is voyaging to Suez. Constructed at Shields, she is of 3,000 h.p.

div.head: The "Kaiserin Elisabeth."
div.p: The Austrian cruiser "Kaiserin Elisalieth" arrived here this morning. Tomorrow afternoon from 5 to 7 o'clock a garden party will be given in the Nouzha Gardens by the Austro-Hungarian Consulate.

div.head: The Brinidi Mail.
div.p: The mail for Europe via Port Said and Brindisi will be made up at the G.P.O., Alexandria at 3.10 p.m. on Monday for ordinary correspondence, midday for money orders and insured articles and at noon on Sunday for parcels.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: Between January 1 and June 22ml 002,3-19 tons of coal were imported into Egypt, of which 322,132 tons were Welsh, 97,331 Newcastle, 104,091 Yorkshire, 42,352 Scotch, and 35,850 other qualities. During the corresponding period of last year the coal imports totaled 199.907.

div.head: The Matarieh Disaster.
div.p: The subscriptions collected for the victims of the Matarieh fire have amounted to L.E. 22,722. On the reccomendation of Chitty Bey, the Ministry of Finance has authorized the fishermen of Matarieh to use their old narrow wash nets which were prohibited by the regulations-inaugurated a short time ago.

div.head: New Telephone Lines.
div.p: The Telephone Company of Egypt has been charged by the Government with the installation of 250 lines in Keneh province in the districts of Koss, Edfou, Deshna, and Naghamadi. The object of these new telephone lines telephone lines is to put the police stations of the districts in touch with each other.

div.head: Ophtaimia at Damanhour.
div.p: The perambulating Ophthalmia Hospital has been for some weeks past at Damanhour. The average number of patients treated there is 700 daily at the lowest computation. Crowds flock to the hospital from all parts of the province of Behera. In October next the hospital will go into the Gharbieh province.

div.head: French Agency.
div.p: M. Chevandier de Valdrome will return to Cairo on July 11th via Port-Said He will preside at the Fourteenth of July Fete M. Roux will go on leave after M. de Valdrome's arrival in Cairo. M. de Suyoni who has been appointed student vice consul at the Cairo consulate in place of Comte S.M Bruno Bouchorene de Lacoste who was promoted to vice consul will arrive to take up his position immediately. M. Cossany the consular dragoman went to Europe on leave yesterday.

div.head: Customs Administration.
div.p: The Customs Administration has applied to the Ministry of Finance for a credit of LE 4,000 for the construction of depots for imported cement The construction of these depots is necessitated by the increase in the importation of tills article and particularly the large quantities which are expected to he ordered in the future for the raising of the Assuan dam. The Ministry of Finance has submitted the application of the Customs to the Council of Ministers for approval.

div.head: Ministry of Education.
div.p: From the recent credit of 1.11 68,3V 9 granted to the Ministry of Education, the following are the details of expenditure —LE. 17,783 for professional and agricultural teaching ; LE. 8,574 for the new cadis school ; LE. 3,300 for the agricultural and professional schools; LE. 7,378 for the inspection of schools , LE. 3,400 for sending students to Europe, LE. 1,828 for the construction of a school for kuttah teachers, LE 8,480 for mollification in the primary course, and LK. 8,890 for the secondary course, and LE. 5,533 for higher education and LE 436 for girls' schools.

div.head: French Fate at Cairo.
div.p: The preparations for the celebration of the fête on July 14th are progressing at Cairo. A triumphal arch is being constructed at the Charieh Kamel entrance to the Esbekieh gardens. This arch will be illuminated on the evening in question. The guests being received in the tent that will be erected opposite the triumphal arch, will witness an operetta and a comedy in the open air. M. Reffye the French consul will preside at this performance. At the Gardens Theatre, entry to he by payment, the patriotic piece "La Grande Famille" will Ire played. M. Chevandier de Valdrome will pre-side at this part of the tête Both performances will he concluded by the playing of the "Marseillaise."

div.head: EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT. Sir E. Grey's Snubs.
div.p: The following questions were asked in the House of Commons on the 18th sent.

Mr. MacNeill.— To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether, seeing that in Cairo the poor quarters of Boulak, Abassieh, Demerdash, Ghamra, and O'd Cairo have in large parts been demolished to make way for middle-class and upper-class dwellings, and that no provision has been made for the poorer classes ejected by the demolition, he will advise the Egyptian Government to prepare a Scheme for the better housing of the working Classes of that city.

Sir Edward Grey :— His Majesty's Government have no reason to suppose that the Egyptian Government are neglecting this question, hut the matter is not one on which Any advice can usefully be tendered. It is very desirable that the subject should receive attention in Egypt as elsewhere, but progress must be gradual.

Mr. Mac Neill.—To ask the Secretary of Estate for Foreign Affairs, whether he will Advise the British Agent at Cairo to consider the expediency of cancelling Article 89 of the Official Code of Regulations, relating to school Organisation and discipline which enacts that pupils arc strictly forbidden, under penalty of Expulsion from the school, to supply any information, to write any letters or articles to newspapers, or to become agents for any paper.
Sir Edward Grey.—I have not seen the Article in question, but the Code of Regulations must be decided by the Egyptian Educational authorities.

div.head: THE CASSA DI SCONTO
div.p: Some of the shareholders of the Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio are trying to form a group in order to consider what means should betaken with a view to the protection of their interests and to decide on the line of policy to be followed at the meeting on next Tuesday.

They are fully determined to insist on the responsibilities of the Board of Directors of the Bank. If they can form a compact group, representative of a number of the shareholders, they will hold a meeting tomorrow or the day after in order to draw up the plan of campaign, which they intend to follow.

div.head: BOURSE AND BANKING CO. LTD. The Board's Suggestion.
div.p: A number of shareholders of the Bourse and Banking Company Limited, have decided to wait before coining to any definite decision as to accepting the suggestions made by the Board of Directors of this company, until a clear exposé has been made of the exact situation of the concern. The position is now being ascertained by accountants, and when the accounts are presented before an extra ordinary general meeting of the shareholders, which, it is presumed, will be convened, then some division can be arrived at.

div.head: THE SCHOOL OF LAW
div.p: This public School is fast becoming a club for Nationalists and agitators with most of the students as members and Mustafa Kamel as president. On several occasions the law students went out of their way to support the party of sedition, a course unwarranted by the condition of their country and untolerated by any Government under similar circumstances These youthful friends of the agitator were on the platform of the Station on Tuesday last to bid Mustafa Kamel farewell with all the noise and parade of an infuriated political party.

They were among the first to sign the seditious document published at the office of "Al Lewa" for party purposes in support of a free pardon for the Denishwai criminals, a document that attacked the Government in the most violent and unjustified terms, while it described the decision and sentence as illegal and unjust. These related irregularities make us believe that the administration of that great public school was not all that could be desired.

The appointment of an Englishman to preside over the School of Law after such occurrences has been a laudable and beneficial change in our view. That school is in urgent need of a strong hand for directing its administration as it has been without a president with administrative qualifications for many years. The former French presidents were eminently qualified, professionally, for the post now filled by Mr, Hill; that professional ability does not suffice for directing the affairs of a great public school in this country. It is, of course, the principal qualification for teachers in as much as administrative efficiency is the main qualification for the president of a high school. "Al Watan").

div.head: DENISHWAI REVIVED. Bernard Shaw's Latest. A Remarkable Chapter.
div.p: In turning over the pages of Mr. Bernard Shaw's latest production, "John Bull's Other Island" (Archibald Constable and Co. Ltd., London) the attention of Anglo-Egyptians is naturally attracted to a remarkable chapter of the preface, dragged out to the extent of 69 pages) entitled the "De Horror," which, is led up to by a general attack on the British soldier ("Down with the Soldier"). "For permanent work," says the great Bernard Shaw, "the soldier is worse than useless ; such efficiency as he has is the result of dehumanization and disablement. His whole training tends to make him a weakling. He has the easiest of lives ; he has no freedom and no responsibility. He is politically and socially a child, with rations instead of rights, treated like a child, punished like a child, dressed prettily and washed and combed like a child, excused for outbreaks of naughtiness like a child, forbidden to marry like a child, and called Tommy like a child. He has no real work to keep him from going mail except housemaids work...
His officer has not even housemaid's work to keep him sane.

Certainly there are few, and probably there are none, who take Bernard Shaw seriously. His writings are obviously too exaggerated, and not infrequently too flippant, to receive serious consideration. Most certainly his style is original, and originality always attracts attention, and is in many cases meritorious, but throughout his writings there runs a forced vein of humor, mingled with feeble witticisms which greatly detracts from the value of his work.

Turning to the chapter on "The Denishwai Horror" ;— Mr. Shaw compares the officer's shooting expedition to that village to "a party of Chinese officers suddenly appearing in an English village and beginning to shoot the ducks, the geese, the hens and the turkeys, and carrying them off, asserting that they were wild birds, as everybody in China knew, and that the pretended indignation of the farmers was a cloak for hatred of the Chinese, and for a plot to overthrow the religion of Confucius and establish the Church of England in its place" What wonderful, what Shaw like logic! What strange and even weird deductions to draw from the severe punishment of semi-barbarian fellaheen for an exceptionally brutal and unwarranted attack on officers wearing the British uniform!

On what authority Mr. Shaw assorts that the officers "went from 100 to 300 yards away from the houses (these distances were afterwards officially averaged at 500 yards) and began shooting the pigeons" it is impossible for us to say, but we can assure him from personal knowledge that his informant was as misguided as himself. It is possible that the outrage might have been avoided had the officers shown resistance in the first instance, and there is justice in the criticism that they should not have surrendered their guns and offered backlash, but a mistaken effort at conciliation is no excuse tor a display of excessive brutality resulting in murder. The position in which Major Fine Coffin was placed was an exceedingly difficulty one, and he was at the beginning under the erroneous impression that the woman had been accidentally shot by Lieutenant Porter, whereas it was her fellow villagers who had caused the explosion of the gun.

But we do not wish to weary our readers with a recapitulation of the evidence, which we gave so fully at the time of the trial, and we feel assured that none of them will be misled by Mr. Shaw's distortions. Mr. Shaw, indeed, in the very chapter referred to, voluntarily offers himself to the charge of misrepresentation, for he says "I fear I have stated their (presumably the villager's) case very unfairly and inadequately, because I am hampered, as an Irishman, by my implacable hostility to English domination." Surely a man who confesses to considering such a rase from a parti pris point of view is unworthy of serious consideration?

Mr. Shaw continues:—"Mistrusting my own prejudices, I have taken the story from the two parliamentary papers in which our officials have done their utmost to whitewash the tribunals and the pigeon shooting party, and to blackwash the villagers." To illustrate his use of the parliamentary papers we might quote the following, which will give one readers a good idea of the flippancy and insincerity of his writing : —

"Abdel Nebi, in consideration of the injury to his wife, was only sentenced to penal servitude for life. And our clemency did not stop there. His wife was not punished at all, not even charged with stealing the shot which was found in her person. And lest Abdel Nebi should feel lonely at 25 in beginning penal servitude for the rest of his days, another young man, of 20, was sent to penal servitude for life with him." Oh noble judge, oh most upright judge! What excellent use you have made of the parliamentary papers ; what complete and unbiased evidence of the case you have placed before those who will peruse your pages!

To quote another passage, referring to Hassan Mahfouz: - "An Egyptian pigeon farmer (sic) who objects to British sport ; threatens British officers and gentlemen when they shoot his pigeons ; and actually hits those officers with a substantial stick, is clearly a ruffian to lie made an example of. Penal servitude was not enough for a man of fit) who looked 70, and might not have lived to suffer five years of it Ru Hassan was hanged ; but as a special mark of consideration for his family, he was hanged in view of his own house, with his wives and children and grandchildren enjoying the spectacle from the roof." The casual reader, opening the book and glancing at the pages haphazardly would, on coming across such paragraphs, exclaim "whoever is the author of that?" but turning to the cover or the title page would significantly remark "Oh, it's Bernard Shaw!" The careful reader, noting the name of the author before opening the book, would recognise immediately that he was about to read something remarkable, but in no way serious.

div.head: THE MEDITERRANEAN FLEET. Visit to Alexandria.
div.p: Sir Eldon Gorst, who returned to Alexandria last night from Mariout, paid a visit to the "Queen" this morning and was received by Admiral Sit Charles Drury, Prince Louis of Battenberg, and the officers of the flagship. The flagship was also visited this morning by Mustapha Pasha Ibadi and Hopkinson Bey. The departure of the Governor from the vessel was signaled by a salute of 11 guns.
The Admirals, Captains, and Officers have been elected honorary members of the British Club.
PROGRAMME OF ENTERTAINMENTS

Monday, 1st July.— Cricket Mitch commencing 10.30 a.m. Fleet v. Alexandria. Cricket Ground opposite the British Consulate. Players to lunch at the Union Club and to take tea on the ground. Mrs. K. P. Birley and Mrs. H. B.Carver "At Home."

Khédivial Yacht Club "At Home" to officers of the fleet. 4.30 to 6 p.m. Sailing Race for all service rigs. Cup presented by members of K.Y.C. Men will be entertained to light refreshments at the Y'acht Club after race.
Tuesday, 2nd July.- Lunch given by British colony to midshipmen of fleet at Aboukir, Tea on return offered by Mrs. Robert J. Moss, at Colline Moss, Ramleh.
The Alexandria Swimming Club will entertain the men at aquatic carnival including polo, tug of war, 4 to 6 p.m. at Ras-el-Tin.

div.head: E.R.A. LOCOMOTIVES
div.p: During the past year 50 locomotives were received from Europe during the year: eleven old ones were broken up and seven sold; seven narrow gauge engines which formerly belonged to the Port Said line have been deducted from the stock, being of no further use, which give* a total of engines in service at the end of 1906 of 567. — The average number of engines for the past year was 554 of which an average of 118 engines have been standing and under going repairs, leaving 436 in service. 96 of those have been engaged in shunting and 340 on regular train services. The 30 engines purchased during the .year consisted of 17 four wheel coupled passenger engines, two-cylinder type, from the North British Locomotive Company, Glasgow ; 30 similar engines from Messrs. Henschel and Son, Cassel ; and three narrow gauge six-wheel coupled engines from America, for use on the Luxor-Assouan line. One of the engines built for the Administration in Germany was sent to the Milan Exhibition. The average age of engines in 1906 was twelve years, as against fourteen years in 1905. The total engine kilométrage was 21,497,752 against 19,641,663 in 1505, which gives an increase of 1,866,089, - or 9.4 %. The average yearly kilométrage per engine engaged on regular train service works out at 44,394 kilometers. During the year, 235 engines underwent thorough repairs, and in addition 208 engines had light repairs carried out in the workshops. The number of engines fitted with the automatic vacuum brake on December 31st 1906 was 233 ; twelve have been fitted with the front connection and fourteen with steam brakes.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA. The Building of a City. Building Laws.
div.p: When some twenty three centuries ago the architects were commissioned by the great Alexander to build the city which was to carry his name down the ages, they doubtless cast about them for their precedents and procedures ; indeed, Mr. J. P. Mahaffy in his history of the Ptolemaic Dynasty says, the ancient city of Alexandria "was laid out on the principles which the architect Hippodamus had made fashionable in Greece," which proves incidentally that "principles" for the planning of cities were already in existence as well as fashionable architects. Those "principles" have long been lost to Alexandria, especially one of the most useful of them, namely, that which made the main thoroughfares equal to u width of 32 metres—think of a Cherif Pasha Street 32 metres wide! In the olden times there was at least breadth.

But the Athenian architects had before their eyes the city of the goddess Athena in its prime. The dazzling, white Pentelikon marble wrought by the skill of the Greek masons into the beautiful lines and proportions of the Parthenon, which crowned the Acropolis and which in turn crowned the abode of inspired art, set amidst olive green hills and peaks. It was a city of inspiration to architects and of inspired artists and thence came the architects who built ancient Alexandria.

Yet Egypt itself was not lacking in ancient cities and principles of planning, whence probably, ages before the old Greeks themselves received their inspiration. On, Memphis, Luxor, and Thebes afforded, in their too early decay, precedents of grandeur, width and scale and charm of design and workmanship. The architects, however, who were sent from the office of Hippodamus looked upon the Parthenon from afar, out at sea, as they sailed from the Piraeus over 2,300 years ago, even as voyagers from Greece to Alexandria may do in these days. The architects came and built their theaters and Hypostyle halls and their libraries, museums, and studions. But where are they? In Athens the Theseum stands to this day practically intact and the noble remains of the Parthenon are a standing witness to the evils of grim passion and gunpowder. But where are the many-columned halls of Alexandria? Is it that Athens is built upon a rock and Alexandria upon the sand? Be that as it may, there are unmistakable proofs that much of modern Alexandria stands upon the fallen columns of the Greek Architects. A number of these were discovered a year ago, when the foundation was being dug for the large house now nearing completion adjacent to the Victoria school. The shafts of several columns had fallen across each other and lay about six metres below the surface. The material was granite brought from Assouan, and they were wrought beautifully after the principles of the Parthenon. The fluting was skillfully done showing incidentally how the Greek workman could turn his hand from the more easily worked marble to the tough and rough grained granite. It is a thousand pities that those most interesting remains of Alexander's city were not brought to the surface.

The total disappearance of the ancient city, save the pillar set up by pro-consul Pompeius, is a matter for grave reflection. The ancient builders were not always careful of their foundations, of this many of the ancient temples of Egypt bear witness. And this not, withstanding the excellent building laws formulated by Moses, who received his training in Egypt twenty five centuries ago, and the more drastic laws, because of the death penalty for transgression, enacted by Khammurabi long anterior to the day of Moses. These considerations and the oft recurring building accidents in Alexandria, Cairo and elsewhere call urgently for a code of building laws for Alexandria and Egypt generally.

That some tentative regulations, administered by the Tanzims as to alignments and widths of streets are in existence, we know, but this only emphasized the need of some security for the dwellers and passers by, that the erections which the Municipality is so careful to align should be soundly built.
(To be continued.)

div.head: WEDDING AT PORT SAID.
div.p: A quiet wedding took place at the English Church, Port Said, on the 27th inst., when Ernest Willmott of the K.T.C., Suez, eldest son of Capt. Willmott (late Shropshire Light Infantry) and Irene Hickie, eldest daughter of H. Hickie Esq., Cork, were joined together in matrimony. Canon Strange performed the ceremony. Mr. Anderson gave the bride away, and Mr. Dowson acted as best man. Mr. and Mrs. Willmott spent a few days in Port Said before proceeding to Suez.

Dr. Wagner, Secretary of Legation, will set for the Count during his absence.
The German Agency will be under the direction of Count Breeder during the absence of Count von Bernsdorff.
Mr. Silferverghelm, the consular representative of Sweden at Alexandria, will manage the Brazilian Consulate General here during the absence of Count Debbane.

div.head: OBITUARY. Muzaffer Pasha.
div.p: According to a telegram, which arrived at Alexandria from Beyrout, Marshal Muzaffer Pasha, Governor-General of the Lebanon, died suddenly at Beyrout yesterday. The cause of death was heart disease. He was appointed to the Governorship five years ago and his period of office was to have expired on the 15th September next. The deceased was of Armenian and Polish origin and was an Ottoman subject. He was formerly an A.D.C. of the Sultan. His tenure of office in Syria has not been very successful and many were the complaints against his methods of Government.

The late Pasha was, however, strongly supported by the British Consular authorities at Beyrout and it was expected that British influence would be employed to secure his nomination for a second term of office.
The position of Governor General of the Lebanon is a very difficult one as the Lebanon is a regular hornet's nest of political intrigue.
It is believed that the son of Franco Pasha will succeed him. The chances of Sir Edward Zohrab Pasha as a successor are also spoken of. The Governor General of the Lebanon must be a Christian.

div.head: K.S.C. POLO.
div.p: Polo in Cairo, in spite of the absence on leave of many players, is still flourishing. On Thursday 25th., no less than 36 players were on the grounds. Three good matches were played.
The Coldstream Guards No. 1., team played the K.O.S.B. No. 1. team.

This was an excellent match, play being fast and keen throughout. The K.O.S.B, started well, scoring 2 goals the first chukker, but they failed to keep up this form, the Coldstream Gnards eventually winning by 4 goals to 2.

The British delegates proposed at the Naval Commission the prohibition of the employment of unmoored submarine mines or mines liable to drift, and the restriction of the use of mines to territorial waters adjoining naval bases and fortified ports. Notice of the laying of mines most he given to neutrals, and an endeavor must be made to prevent the destruction of unnoticed merchantmen. (Reuter)

The Chamber of Deputies has voted confidence in the Government's policy regarding the wine agitation by 323 to 233 votes. M. Clemenceau declared that the Royalists were conducting an insurrectionary campaign in the South. He said that tire troops would be withdrawn when the law was respected. (R.)
M. Clemenceau, in answer to questions on the state of affairs in the South, replied that the Government had decided to continue the democratic social régime and will not abandon its work.
After a whole night sitting the Chamber 'passer! a vote of confidence in tire Government by 324 votes against 233 for the maintenance of the law and peace. (Havas)
The soldiers who mutinied have arrived (U.)

It is announced today that Dr. Béthmann-hollweg, who succeeded Count Pesadowski-Wehner, has been appointed generally to represent Prince von Buelow until further notice. The significance of the announcement is at present unexplained. (Reuter)
A Ukase of the Tsar directs the Issue of 50,000,000 roubles 4 % rente to assist to defray the expenditure for 1907. (Reuter)
Prince Borghese has been stopped by insurmountable obstacles south of lake Baikal. He has returned to Misovik. (Reuter)
The Berlin Chamber of Commerce has decided to organise a universal exhibition. (Havas)
The Italo-Russian treaty of commerce has been completed. (Havas)
Lancashire beat Somerset by an innings and 103 runs. M.C.C. beat Oxford University by an innings and one run. (Reuter)

div.head: SUEZ. Trade in 1906.
div.p: Mr. Pro-Consul Hughes-Laferla reports as follows :—

The trade of Suez did not improve in the course of the year 1906, although the local demand has increased considerably within the last year, owing to the increasing population of Suez and the demands from Port Sudan and other Red Sea ports. The trade for the year 1906 amounted to LE., 1,366,630 or a decrease of L.E. 363,539 as compared with the year 1905. This decrease is shown both in the import and export trades, but principally in the latter. The total value of imports during the year 1906 amounted to LE. 896,942 and the exports to LE 315,490.

The quantity of coal imported at Suez during the year 1906 was 18,134 tons as against 10,382 tons imported in 1905. Of the above quantity 9,191 tons were passed through the customs and paid the full duty of 4 per cent, being for local consumption ; the remainder was taken for ships' bunkers in transit.
4,051 tons of charcoal, valued at LE 10,195 were imported during the year, an increase of 268 tons over the previous year. All of it came from Turkey.
1,200 tons of liquid fuel, valued at LE. 1,170 were deposited in the Shell Company's tanks at Port Tewfik, Suez, as against 7,581 tons in 1905.
51,517 cases of petroleum, valued at LE 8,322 were imported, and also 3,412 tons in bulk, valued at LE 12,161.
A decrease of 1,744 tons is shown in the importation of gunnies, the quantity imported in the year 1906 being 8,313 tons valued at LE 184,977 all of which came from India.
1,537 tons of pepper were imported, valued at LE 62,959, being an increase of 865 tens over the previous year. Nearly all of the pepper came from India.
4,915 tuns of dried dates were imported in the year 1906, valued at LE 34,239. This shows an increase of 589 tons over the year 1905. All the dates came from Basrah.
334 tins of dried fruits were imported, valued at LE.6,509 nearly all coming from India and other British possessions in the East.
1,114 kilos, of tobacco and cigars were imported in 1906 ; 1,027 kilos, less than the previous year.
The number of live cattle and sheep import ed during 1906 is given at 13,977, valued at L.E.5,811 showing a decrease of 3,329 head as compared with 1905.
LE 14,020 worth of underclothing was imported, being an increase of L. E 1,225 over the previous year.

The export trade for the year 1906 shows a decrease of LE230.203 as compared with the year 1905. This decrease is attributed to the decline in the exportation of refined sugar by the Sucreries and Raffinerie Company of Egypt.

Only 1,803 tons of Egyptian refined sugar, valued at LE32,570 were exported during the year 1906, the greater part of which was shipped to Jeddah. This shows a decrease of 17,297 tons, valued at LE.230.iKJ0 as compared with the previous year.
6,393 tons of gum were exported, valued at LE 130,900, an increase of 1,578 tons in weight And L.E 12,906 in value for the year 1906.

16 1/2 tons of ivory, valued at LE. 10,401, were exported. This shows an increase of 5 tons valued at L.E 3,672 compared with the previous year ; 141 tons of the above quantity were shipped to the United Kingdom.
4 tons of ostrich feathers, valued LE 7,452 were exported, against 2 1/2 tons, at valued at LE 4,864 in 1905. The United Kingdom took the whole quantity.
21,772 ardebs of wheat, valued at LE. 21,554, were exported. Almost all was shipped to Turkish ports in the Red Sea.
1,308 ardebs of lentils, values! at L.E 3,999, were exported to Turkish ports in the Red Sea.
723,823 skins, valued at L.E 33,268, were exported. One-half was sent to France and the remainder to the United Kingdom, Belgium and the Netherlands.
The value of re-exported goods was LE 46,199.
The total value of goods which passed in transit through the Suez customs was 8,049 L.E, all of which came from the United Kingdom.

The value of gold imported in specie, as declared at the custom house, was L.E. 128,721 and that exported L.E 39,435. The silver imported in specie was declared at L.E 6,453 and that exported at LE 519.

The Khédivial Mail Company have the whole busmen of carrying Egyptian pilgrims. The trade appears to be very lucrative, as each year daring the pilgrim season other vessels of different companies come to Suez for the purpose of competing in the carrying trade of foreign pilgrims. The following is a return showing the number of pilgrims that passed through Suez with their respective nationalities, viz. :—

Egyptians, 17,971, Ottomans, 7,462, Persians, 174, British Indians, Ac., 251, Russians, 3,905, French (Algerians), 424, Germans, 13, Dutch, 12, Afghans, 90, Austro-Hungarians, 14, Spaniards, 17, Italians, l, Total 30,334

This is an increase of 9,507 pilgrims on the number that passed through Suez in the year 1905. The increase in the Egyptian pilgrims may be safely attributed to the prosperity of the native (Fellah) cultivators of Egypt. The number of pilgrims that [Missed direct through the Suez Canal were 19,610.

The carrying trade of the Red Sea from Suez continues to he almost exclusively in the hands of the Khédivial Mail Company. The rates of freight for cargo have been reduced by about 50 per cent since the previous year. The mail service between Suez and Port Sudan and Suakin is still being maintained once a week, the departure from Suer, being every Wednesday. Other liners have now made Port Sudan a port of call ; they are the British India Steamship Company, the British East Africa Lino, the Hamburg-America Line, the Norddeutscher-Lloyd, the West Hartlepool Steam Navigation Company, and the Frank Strick Company Line. As most of the vessels, however, carry a direct trade with Port Sudan, for the present they take very little or no cargo from Suez.

The number of casualties to British vessels reported to this Consulate during the year 1906 were II, none of which however, was accompanied with loss of life; they were as follows :—7 vessels grounded in the Suez Canal; 2 vessels with damage to machinery, 2 vessels having experienced heavy weather, and 1 vessel haring stranded in Suez Bay.
The importation of coffee was 1,478 tons valued at 71,878 L.E., being an increase of 201 tons over the previous year.

A slight decrease is again shown in the importation of indigo, the quantity imported for the year 1906 being 476 tons, valued at 117,564 LE. The artificial or synthetic indigo (all of which was imported from Germany into Egypt through Alexandria) has increased from 306 tons in 1905 to 391 tons in 1906.

'Die importation of tea has almost doubled during the past year. The quantity imported in 1906 was 420 tons, valued at 19,519 LE. 409 tons were imported from India and other British possessions in the Far East, and 11 tons from China.

A decrease of 10,989 tons is shown in the importation of sugar for the year 1906, the quantity imported last year being 6,435 tons, valued at 80,455 L.E. Nearly the whole of the above quantity is raw sugar imported from Java by the Sucreries and Raffinerie Company of Egypt, to he refined for re-exportation. Several of its refineries have, however, been closed, and the importation of raw sugar has been accordingly restricted.
An increase is again shown in the importation of cotton twist, the quantity imported for the year being 134 tons, valued at 8,599 L.E. Nearly all of this came from India.

The importation of silica amounted to LE. 21,067. This shows a decrease in value of L.K. 1,274 for 1906. All the raw silk was imported from China, and the greater part of the manufactured silk from Japan.

As anticipated in my last report, the importation of cotton from Suakin has greatly increased ; in fact it has more than doubled in quantity since the previous year, the quantity imported for 1906 being 1,260 tons.
530 tons of cotton seed were imported from Suakin in the same period.

The importation of gum from Suakin was 2,589 tons. The gum is sent to Suez for storage. It is then selected and divided, according to quality, white and red, large and small, and then re-exported, according to demand.

The number of carpets imported in 1906 was I 7,183, valued at L.E 35,621, or a decrease of 16,921 in number and of LE 26,002 in value in comparison with the previous year. Almost all were imported from Persia.
218 tons of rice were imported, valued at L K 1,853. This shows a decrease of 87 tons as compared with the previous year. The greater part of the rice was imported from India.
629 tons of sesame seeds were imported, valued at LE 7,696, being 348 tons less than that imported in 1905. The greater part came from India and other British possessions.

div.p: RIFLE SHOOTING.

The Match between teams from H.M.S. "Diana" and the B.R.C. on Thursday, resulted in a win for the latter by 14 points. Several marksmen on both sides fell off rather unaccountably at 600 yards. A return match will will probably take place next Thursday afternoon.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: It is hoped that the rumour will turn out false that thousands of imperfect lyddite shells have been issued to the service. Those who man our guns are sufficiently exposed to danger from the fire of the enemy without having to face this new terror. If there is any truth in the statement it is shocking that persons could he so base and callous to the interests of their country and the lives of their fellow creatures as, for the sake of a few paltry pounds to issue miseries of the kind which would be more dangerous to the users than to the adversary. We hope, however, that the investigation about to be held will show that the charge and suspicions have been entirely groundless.
Second Lieutenant R. M. Watson, Royal Dublin Fusiliers, on first appointment has been posted to 2nd Battalion, but will not join the 1st Battalion at Alexandria.
There are now 190 British officers serving under the Egyptian Government in the Khedive's army, or holding other appointments.
Second Lieutenant C.L. Gordon, 2nd Battalion Coldstream Guards, has been promoted lieutenant.

The changes in the King's Royal Rifle Corps next October, by the retirement of Colonel W.S. Says from the command of the 2nd Battalion, will bring Major R.S. Oxley, second in command of the 1st battalion at Khartoum and Cairo, to the head of the majors' list. He will not have long to wait for promotion most likely, last the command of the 3rd Battalion, which is under orders to leave Aldershot for Crete in the coming relief season, will fall vacant early in the New Year, and in the usual course of events the step should be given to him.

In reply to Mr. Rees, M.P. in the House of Commons the other day, Mr. Edmund Robert' son, Naval Parliamentary Secretary, stated that under the present arrangement the gunboats Redbreast and Lapwing, with the special service ship Sphinx, East Indies Squadron, were told off for special duty in the Persian Gulf, and from time to time other ships of the squadron visited the Gull Alt this is very good in its way, but the turbulent tribesmen of the Gulf, and the practically disposed floating population require, to be impressed by something more formidable than an antiquated gunboat, or the old paddle-wheeler Sphinx. Mr. Rees pressed Mr. Robertson to send more representative cruisers up the Gulf, and his

request drew applause from all parts of the House. It is quite evident that the cheese paring policy of the Admiralty has not the sanction of the representatives who have the interests of the country at heart.

The Army Council is presently experimenting with n new emergency ration for army-mounts, and several consignments of the stuff have been put out for trial amongst the home cavalry brigades. It is understood that the ration is made up of a certain proportions of carrots, fresh raw meat, currents, sugar, and cocoa leaf, with a little added formate of soda to prevent souring. Such a toothsome ration might help u man along on a pinch. The stuff is to be knocked about on rapid reconnaissance work, and other service likely to occur in the Held when it is desirable not to hamper the eyes of the army by heavy forage transport. In each case an expert veterinary officer will supervise the trials of the rations.

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE. Coton.
div.p: L'allure Un marché pétulant la semaine qui vient de finir a été, sinon absolument, du moins presque identique à celle de la huitaine précédente: les séances fermes ont succédé aux séances faibles et en baisse et vice-versa, avec des changements continuels dans les prix, mais le tout so réduisant à de petites fractions et finissant pur se résumer en des différences pour ainsi dire insignifiantes sur les cours renseignés dans notre revue de Vendredi dernier, l'n autre point de ressemblance entre les deux reculées consiste dans lu divergence des résultats auxquels ont abouti les efforts des intéressés pour les deux récoltes, mais sur ces deux points nous reviendrons plus loin.

En attendant, ce que nous pouvons dire, c'est au une tenue pareille indique pour le moins de I indécision de lu part des haussiers ; mais si, après tout, cette hésitation des acheteurs n'a cessé de se faire remarquer, le fait en lui-même n a rien détonnant pour peu que l'on tienne compte de ce que rarement marché a été aussi restreint, uussi jieu gujdé ou iutlucucé par les nouvelles de l'étranger et, en définitive, n'ayant pour le diriger qu'un petit groupe d'intéressé» dont la ténacité et la persévérance mériteraient une meilleure récompense.

En somme, (nous avons en tout simplement un marché de transition ou dut lento et l'effet qu'ont pu produire Itjs clôtures d'Amérique, suivant qu'elles veiuiicut en hausse gu en baisse, et l'impression que, selon leur importance, produisaient les exportations, ont constamment été tout momentanés, et si, tante de mieux, ils ont été pris comme prétexte n manipulations, le but visé n'a jamais été atteint à moins qu'on ne pn-teiiile que ce but a consisté simplement dans le soutien des cours. Voilà tout ce que nous pouvons dire comme description de l'état des choses dans lequel nous nous trouvons.

Quant à la marche journalière des évènements, elle est représentée par les fluctuations suivantes : Samedi, hausse de 5 32 pour le Novembre ; Lundi retour au punt de départ ; Mardi, reprise au niveau de Samedi ; Mercredi, nouvelle amélioration de 1 Hi et, finalement. Jeudi et Vendredi, recul de .132, ce qui lait que la cote du jour à laquelle clôture la semaine est de 20 1/32, soit en tout l/H de hausse. Ce n'est pas lourd, mais cela démontre In fermeté de la nouvelle récolte.

Is- Juillet, dans ses hauts et lias, a procède de concert avec le Novembre, mais dans des proportions qui n'ont fait que graduellement s'écarter do façon que le résumé pour cette échéance est tout bonnement 1/10 de Isiisse sur Vendredi dernier.
Comme chiffre d'affaires, il n'y a rien Je Ml n ut à relever, ni pour Juillet, ni pour le Novembre.

Dans les conditions que nous venons d exposer, le repirt de Juillet à Novembre est. donc maintenant de 13, 32 do tallari. au lieu de T 32, comme cela ressortait de la cote d il y a huit jours et, par conséquent, les détenteurs du Juillet n'ont juin lieu d'être tout à fait satisfaits. Néanmoins, la mauvaise humeur ne peut que diminuer si l'on considère que nous sommes à deux jours de l'échéance, que la retraite de la filature du marché depuis nue diraine de jours est complète et que le (luttant se trouve éparpillé entre des mains faillies.

Il est vrai qu'à cela on pourrait objecter : mais que fera le commerce d'exportation jnnin tenant que l'écart entre la vieille et la nouvelle récolte parait -i tentant! Ici réponse est facile Nos exportateurs n'ont pas réussi hsedéhar passer de tout le Juillet qu'ils avaient acheté •ai pris en échange de Novembre et comme ils ne sont pis lii uniquement pour dégager la place ou taire l'affaire de la spéculation, ils ont jugé que. dans les conditions financières de la place, leur intérêt leur coinmamlait de se modérer dans leurs achats, par ne pas séxpo serrages débours dans lesquels ils ne pour-raient rentrer que plus tard. l<e jour où la filature se décidera à revenir aux oculiste, ils seront enc re à temps de rifler ce qui reste en circulation en fait de Juillet et de faire leur a flaire.

De plus, la récolte actuelle n'est pas seule à mériter leur attention, et s'ils laissent de côté quelque» disponibilités, l'argent ainsi réservé trouve un meilleur emploi dans l'intérieur, grâce aux conditions exceptionnellement avantageuses auxquelles ils peuvent opérer. Du reste, nous avons déjà signalé le cas dans notre dernière revue et si les affaires de se côté là, qui généralement finissent par être représentées par des ventes de contrats sur Novembre, n'ont pis eu beaucoup d'importance jusqu'au jourd'hui, cela tient a que chacun n'a pas dans sa caisse ou à sa disposition autant du numéraire qu'il le voudrait. Toutefois, petit à petit, ces affaires finiront par s'élever a un joli total et c'est précisément en cela que consiste le danger que d'aucuns appréhendent pair le Novembre.

Certes, la question de la baisse éventuelle du Novembre est discutable en face de I'importance des ventes déjà faites a la consommation et de l'excellence de la situation des filateurs qui, pour beaucoup d'entr'eux, se traduit par des engagements à très longue haleine ; mais, d'autre part aussi, il faut tenir compte que tout ne dqéjiend sis de ces deux points et que la réussite des récoltes aura son rôle à jour jais la suite.

Que la récolte américaine sont petite, nous verrons sûrement des prix extraordinaires pour les cotons égyptiens, même s'ils sont abondants ; mais si, par contre, elle réussit et comme qualité et comme quantité, croit on que nos cotons pourront se maintenir à des écarts anormaux au-dessus de l'americain? Nous ne demandons pas que l'on escompte cette dernière éventualité ; mais est-ce que ce ne serait pas le cas, pour ceux qui ont par devise "Excélsior," de ne pas oublier que le niveau de 20 tallaris n'eat pas modéré et qu'un peu de prudence ne serait pas hors de prepos?
Il est vrai que Trice qui manigance nu coup

sur Août, a lancé que première estimation de 11.000.000 de balles, basée sur le dernier rap port de Miss Giles. Seulement, ce que le susnommé ne mentionne pas, c'est que Miss Giles arrête son rapport au là du mois, tandis que le prochain bureau, qui doit paraître au 3 Juillet, ira jusqu'au 25, et que durant toute cette dernière période le temps a été phénoménalement favorable. De plus, l'estimation ci-dessus est calculée sur une étendue de 32 700.000 acres, tandis que l'opinion générale est que l'acréogo réel n'est pis inférieur à 35.000.000 d'acres.

Cortes, Price pourrait quand même finir par avoir raison si la s'cheresse devait venir à s'en mêler avec quelque Killing front par plus tard pour favoriser les idées haussières : mais comme on ne saurait tabler sur ce qui pourrait survenir, mais simplement sur ce que Ton a devant soi, le hou sens impose que Ton ne fasse pas trop de cas de ces épitres enflammées que Trice excelle à rédiger et à propager quand son intérêt est en jeu.

Jusqu'à present, nous n'avons pas entendu parler de pronostics pour le prochain bureau, ni de rapports particuliers ; il est, cependant, certain que ces sortes de renseignements ne doivent pas tarder à nous venir.

En attendant, cher, nous, les choses sont au mieux et le 2 Juillet nous aurons le résumé de l'Alexandrin General Produce Association. A ce propos nous ajouterons que les premières réponses reçues an questionnaire de Juin sont toutes favorables : temps chand et ayant fait rattraper, sinon tout, du moins une partie. du retard, eau suffisante et presque suis de dégâts par le vers. C'est l'idéal, pour ainsi dire, mais malheureusement ce n'est qu'à partir du 15 Août que commettre la période critique ' Hn tous cas, pour le moment, on ne saurait souhaiter mieux et c'est déjà quelque chose.
Le marché du disponible a donné lieu à quelques affaires dans le courant de la semaine, mais il finit calme.

Comme prix, cependant, il reste soutenu, salas qu'il y ait rien île saillant, toute la modification à hi cote restant limitée à l/H de hausse sur les Mit Attifiez sur les provenances Haute Egypte. Les Loannovich sont sans changement.

Quant aux exportations, elles ont été des plus satisfaisantes, leur total ayant fini par dépasser très sensiblement les prévisions eu atteignant le chiffre de 6.600 Balles, contre 7.700 Tannée dernière.

Pour la semaine prochaine on parle de fortes quantités ne faisant pis triste figure n la comparison avec les embarquements de la période correspondante eu 1906, qui a été d'une dizaine de mille halles.

Ce sera du reste la première semaine du mois et cela.semblera fort naturel , mais eu même temps ce qui devient fort intéressant à observer c'est la rapidité de la disparition du surplus de la récolte. Sur le million de Cantars en plus, il ne reste que 50,000 Cantars et pour peu que nous ayons deux semaines de bonnes expéditions, nous serons à égalité avec 1906 comme ressources pour le restant de la campagne. Dans l'absorption de ces 950,000 Cantars, tous les pays ont participé. l'Angleterre pour 50,000 Halles, le Continent pour 20,000 et l'Amérique pour 39,000.
Cela a été une chance par l'Egypte; souhaitons seulement qu'elle continue pour l'année prochaine, no fût ce que pour lui offrir une compensation partielle à ce qu'elle a perdu depuis trois mois!
Liverpool a été un peu plus actif pour les égyptiens disponibles, mais pour ce qui est des prix, le spit finit eu perle de I 16, à la cote de 10 7/16.
Par contre, les futurs ont profité d une bâtisse de 8/64, la cote du Juillet étant aujourd'hui de 10 19/64.

Les américains ont absolument manqué d animation, mais sons le rapport des prix, ils ont été quand même assez favorisés: les disponible a gagné pendant la semaine 11 points en revenant au cours de 7.15, tandis que les futurs s'inscrivent ce soir a 6.68 pour le Juillet Août et 6.39 pour l'Octobre Novembre, soit respectivement 14 et 13 points de hausse.

div.head: Graines de Coton.
div.p: Les recettes ont été petites, comparativement aux besoins de l'exportation, mais cette circonstance un pas empêché les prix dé baisser jusqu'au niveau de T.T. ho.
Cela semble curieux ; toutefois, l'explication de ce fait est très facile : ce n'est pas le manque de demande qui eu est la cause, mais bien la situation des contrats.

Hn effet, ceux ci ont eu mie tenue déplorable, tant à cause de l'inertie et île la baisse de Hull, que des réalisations de la speculation, impressionnée, outre mesure peut-être/ par l'approche de l'échéance Juillet. Le dernier cours pour ce mois est de T.T. 81 1/2.
Hull, au lieu d'acheter, offre de revendre, la récolte actuelle à £ 7 17/6. Probablement quelque spéculateur qui veut ce débarrassce de quelque chose.
les huiles sont pourtant toujours dans la même situation.
La nouvelle récolte est soutenue chez, nous-et finit à T.T. 70 3/4.
A Hull aussi elle se maintient bien entre £ 7 1/3 et 7 2 6 acheteurs. Tas beaucoup d'affaires cependant.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: C'est dans de bien mauvaises conditions que la semaine a débuté ; en même temps que la Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio fermait ses portes vendredi dernier, l'association des courtiers eu valeurs, renonçant à la lutte, fermait aussi les siennes; ce qui ne veut pas dire que les transaction» aient été suspendues, bien nu contraire. la's spéculateurs affolés ont vendu hors bourse autant qu'ils ont pu et à des prix très bas (In National Bank a été traitée à 16 livres et même au-dessous). On pouvait done craindre une débâcle pour la prochaine ouverture de la Corbeille des valeurs. Tel a bien-été le cas pour lundi, mais le lendemain, sur une amélioration subite des contra a Londres et à Paris et des rumeurs optimistes mises en circulation an sujet de la Cassa di Sconto, que reprise a eu lieu, qui s'est affirmée trois jours le suite, faisant regagner à nombre-d* valeurs une partie du terrain perdu naguère. On eu était là quand, et matin, le calme a inopiné ment repris le dessus. On a même pu craindre un moment le retour do la dégringolade, mais en clôture les cours se sont raffermis.

Tour trouver une explication plausible à la réaction baissière de cette semaine, il suffit de se reporter aux faits qui ont accompagné la fermeture de la Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio. Le lendemain même où se produisait ce triste évènement, l'Union Bank assignait cet établissement devant le juge des Référés pour obtenir un séquestre judiciaire, avec pouvoir le prendre possession des actions qui avaient été données à l'Union Bank en gage pour les J millions de francs que celle-ci avait avancé à la Cassa. On conçoit le désarroi occasionné ]sir cette nouvelle, alors que la presse locale et les actionnaires mettaient leur principal espoir dana le secours prompt et large de l'Union Bank, considérée un moment comme le sauveur le la place d'Alexandrie. Heureusement, des pourparlers ayant été aussitôt engagés entre lea deux banques, la sentence du juge des Référés a été renvoyée à plus tard pour a demande des deux parties.

C'était une phase de répit pour les intéressés. Eu même temps on faisait circuler le bruit que le mal n'était pas irréparable, quelles groups's acheteurs de fonds égyptiens se forment a Londres et à Taris pour relever notre place, enfin que Sir Ernest Casuel prendrait une part active dans le combinaison relative à la Cassa di Sconto. Lundi soir, les cours le Londres, en hausse subite et considérable pour les valeurs égyptiennes venant donner corps à ces affirmations, d'ailleurs assez vagues, notre marche a repris confiance et les haussiers int mis tout ce qui leur restait de vigueur pour remonter le niveau de la cote, depuis longtemps à la dérive.

Le fait est que les 1 «lissiers avaient dé liasse toute mesure. Mais que valent au fond, lisent les huissiers, ces affirmation» optimistes, lancées pur nos adversaire»î La situation exacte le la Cassa n'est pas encore connue. lie bilan officiel auquel on est en train de travailler ne sera publié que dans quelque temps. Quelques financiers occupés à l'évaluation de l'actif lisent, il est vrai, que la proportion des pertes n'est pas aussi considérable qu'on le suppose, mois encore faut il attendre le résultat définitif le leurs travaux. Quant à la prétendue intervention île Sir Ernest Casse), c'était tout simplement un guard auquel on vient de couper les ailes. Reste la formation île groupes acheteurs dans le» places dirigeantes d'occident. Les baissiers en nient tout simplement l'existence et donnent pour unique motif delà hausse actuelle le- rachats du découvert Redoutant un revirement subit de la tendance générale à l'approche de la liquidation, ils se hâtent le racheter avec un fort bénéfice ce qu'ils ont vendu un commencement du mois. .S'il fallait les en croire la baisse aussi bien que la hausse serait leur ouvrage et ils seraient prêts à recommencer dans quelques jour* cette opération qui leur a si bien réussi.

Il peut y avoir du vrai dans ces allégations, mais, si les circonstances ne leur viennent pas en aide, les pessimistes feront bien de s'abstenir, attendu qu'aux cours avantageux actuels leurs manœuvres joindraient bien n'avoir pa» le même succès que durant ce mois-ci. Sans revenir sur les lieux commun» tant de fois réédités de la prospérité de l'Egypte et de la plus-value du coton, qu'il nous suffise de constater le rendement actuel des valeurs de premier ordre, telles que la National Bank, l'Agricole, la Delta Light etc. dont la dépréciation fait des placements exceptionnels. Malgré relu, il n'est guère probable que la reprise s'accentue dans de fortes proportions eu égard à la saison morte et aux difficultés financières du moment. Mais, encore une fois, une chute des cours plus prononcée que celle do lundi n'est vraisemblable que dans le ras d'une débâcle proprement dite.

Nous avons déjà dit que la hausse nous venait d'Europe. Il parait, en effet, que la tension monétaire a perdu de son acuité à Londres, puisque le taux privé d'escompte y est revenu de 4 à 3 3/4 0/0. 11 est vrai quels proportion de la réserve de la Banque d'Angle' terre à ses engagements est tombée de 47 1/4 à 42 3/4, ce qui suppose d'importantes sorties. Quoi qu'il en soit, le Consolidé Anglais bénéficie d'une livre et quart à 84 5/8, la Daim de I livre à 111/4. l'Agricole de 3/4 à 8 1/4 la National Bank de près de 3 livres à 20 3/8 et la Delta Light de 1 '2 livre à 9 1/4.

A Paris également les valeurs égyptiennes profitent d'une notable plus-value : le Crédit Policier Egyptien reprend de 665 à 682. La land Bank de 173 à 162 et le Crédit Franco Egyptien de 110 à 114. la Rente Française gagné 33 centimes à 94.30.
Lei, comparée avec le» cours de lundi, l'Agricole regagne 78 à 8 1/16, la National Bank 3 1/16 à 20 1/8, U Unira 1/2 à 14, et la Delta Light l/H à 9 1/8.

Les autres fluctuations les plus importantes à la hausse sont : 1/2 livre sur la Béhéra à 27 1/2, 3 livras 1/2 sur les Nungovicb Hotels à 17 1/2, 3/8 sur la Delta Land à 2, ainsi que sur la land Bank à 7 5/16, 1 livre 1/2 sur la part de fondateur Comptoir à 3 3/4, 7/16 sur la Building lands à 2 3/4, 1/2 livre sur l'Union Foncière à -17 8, 9/16 sur le Crédit Franco-Egyptien à 4 9/16, 1 livre 1 4 sur la fondateur United à 3 1/4, 3 livres sur la fondateur Zariffa à 8 et 1/2 livre sur l'action à 3 1 2, 1/2 livre sur la Ramleh 5 1/2.

En hausse encore la Salt and Soda de l6/9 a 18, l'Obligation Crédit Foncier de 310 à 315. la Banque d'Athènes de 109 à 115 1/2, l'Ordinary Khédivial Mail de 21/6 à 22/6, Investment de I 2 à 5/8, les Estates de 11/16 A 7/8, l'Urbaine de 3 7/8 a 4, l'action Comptoir de 3 l'ancienne et 2 7,8 la nouvelle à 3 1/8 et 3 respectivement, le Banco di Roma de 103 à 104, T United de 3/8 à 7/16, les Ritz Hotels de 5/8 à 3/4, l'Helouan de 3/8 à 7/16 ainsi que la Levico.
Les Tramway d'Alexandrie fléchissent, ail contraire, de 160 les Privilégiées et 315 la» Dividendes à 155 et 310 respectivement, la Deferred Delta de 11 1/2 à 11, et la Levant de 19/32 a 9/16.

Toutes les autres valeurs demeurent changement, excepté la Cassa di Sconto dont l'action ancienne hausse de 40 à 45 fr. tandis que la nouvelle fléchit de 65 à 60- H n'y a d'ailleurs pas eu d'affaires pour fixer les cours.
les transactions n'ont eu d'ampleur qu'en Agricole, National Bank, Delta land. Estates et United ; c'est Londres qui a été le principal acheteur.

Mess. Russell, Kerr et Wyatt sont activement occupés à dresser le bilan de la Cassa di Sconto. On ne sait pas -, encore exactement quand ce'travail sera terminé, mais il est probable que les actionnaires de la Cassa, convoqués pour mardi prochain, n'auront pas le temps d'en prendre connaissance avant assemblée. D'après les déclarations officieuse» de notabilités financières, lo résultat de leur investigations sur les comptes de la Cassa aurait dénoté jusqu'à présent une perte de 13 % au maximum sur un chiffre de 1,100,000 livres environ.

div.head: JUDGE OF THE SUPREME COURT
div.p: Suffered Four Months From the After-Effects of the Grip -- Relieved By Pe-ru-na.
Catarrh Victims Susceptible
People who have had catarrh of the head, throat, nose or lungs are much more liable to catch the grip than other people.
The reason for this is that the mucous membranes of the head, nose, throat or lungs are injured by the catarrh and the germs which cause the grip find easy entrance into the system.
It is a well established fact that perfectly sound mucous membranes constitute a barrier to the entrance of disease germs.
The best precaution any one can hare against the grip is to be perfectly free from catarrh.
Peruna a Preventive.
As a preventive of grip, Peruna has done a great deal of good in the world by its beneficial effect upon the mucous membranes.
Catarrh has anoter untoward influence to be noticed in connection with the grip.
Victims of cattarh who have had the grop find themselves after the acute stages have passed, in very weakened and delorable conditions.
After-Effects of Grip.

The whole nervous system is impaired; the digestive organs deranged; the circulation of the blood feeble and irregular. All these symptoms are produced more or less by the grip and especially in people who have had catarrh previous to the grip.
It is no longer merely a theory or an assertion that Peruna is applicable to such cases.
Prompt Relief.
In all of the after-effects of the grip, Peruna gives prompt relief. This has been the experience of such a great multitude of people that Peruna has come to be a standard remedy for these cases.
If a person has not used Peruna to prevent the grip, the next best thing is to use Peruna to remove the after effects of the grip.
A Safe, Reliable Remedy.
Even during the acute stages of the grip, Peruna taken in small, often doses is so efficient that many people use nothing else.
It has been noticed that those who take Peruna during the first stages of the grip generally make a more rapid and complete recovery.
A Most Effective Medicine for La Grippe.

Robt. L. Madison, A.M., Prinicpal of Cullowhee High School, Painter, N.C., is chairman of the Jackson County Board of Education. He is a writer of occassional verse and has contributetd to a number of leading papers and magazines.
In speaking of Peruna, Mr. Madison says: "I am hardly ever without PEruna in my home. Is it the most effective medicine that I have ever tried for la grippe. It also cured my wife of nasal catarrh."
For special directions everyone should read "The Ills of Life," a copy of which surrounds each bottle. Peruna is for sale by all chemists and druggists.

div.head: "INVESTMENTS."
div.p:
"Investments" introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are "Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them"; "Theory of Successful Speculation"; "How to start an Account" ; "The Advantages of 'Call Options'"; "Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities" ; "How to Invest in Mines"; "American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees"; "The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments" ; "General Principles for Investors" ; "Rules for Investors in Mines"; "General Principles for Speculators"; "Stock Exchange Terms," being a glossary for Market Operators; "Stock Exchange Parlance"; "Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money," and "Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities."
"Investments" (148 pages) sent Post Free on mentioning "Egyptian Gazette."
LONDON & PARIS EXCHANGE LIMITED, GENERAL BANKERS. BASILDON HOUSE, BANK, LONDON, E.C.

div.head: L'AGENCE REUTER.
div.p: Monsieur le Directeur de l' "Egyptian Gazette,"

Comme beaucoup d'autres valeurs du meme genre, la Corporation of Western Egypt (Oasis), a subi le contre-coup de la crise. De son point maximum, 1 livre 5/8, elle est tombee depuis longtemps au-dessous d'une demi-livre, exactement 7/16. Encore ce prix est-il nominal, puisqu'il n'y a pas d'acheteurs. Dans ces conditions, je ne m'explique pas l'attitude de l'Agence Reuter, qui persiste a inscrite la Corporation of Western Egypt a Londres avec 16/32 de prime. Y autrait il par hassard une difference de plus d'une livre entre le cours du Stock Exchange et celui d'ici?
Agreez, etc.
Un Actionnaire.
Le Caire, 28 Juin.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny. Notes et Critiques.
div.p: Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres a fléchi hier de 1/8 k 3 3/4 pour cent.

Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a haussé de 1/8 à 84 5/8. L'Unifiée est rest 'e invariée à Khi 1/4. La National Bank est également demeurée inchangée à 20 3,'8. L'Agricole a réactionné de 18 à 8 1/4. La Daira Sanieh de 14 à 14 1/4 et la Delta Light de 1/2 à 9 1/4.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a rétrogradé de 1 franc à 682. La Banque d'Athènes a avancé de 3 francs à 117.

Ici, à la suite de la première impression causée par les cours dc clôture moins encourageants de Londres, le début de la séance de ce matin a été calme, indécis, voire passablement lourd; mais, réflexion faite, on n'a pas tardé à se ressaisir. 11 n'y avait pas, après tout, péril en la demeure parce que, après une reprise continue de plus de 4 livres sur la National Bank, le Stock Exchange n'était pas allé de l'avant et cocufiait sur la position conquise; parce que l'Agricole, la Daira et la Delta Light avaient quelque peu réaction. D'ailleurs, le taux de l'escompte libre avait baissé et le Consolidé anglais continuait son mouvement ascensionnel. La situation générale n'avait donc pas subi une modification défavorable.
Aussi bien on n'a pas tardé à reprendre confiance êt à regagner rapidement le terrain perdu. La clôture, très active, s'est même faite sur des plus-values appréciables.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National, qui avait été ramenée en moment à 19 11/16-3/4, a fini à 20 1/4. L'Agricole, plus faible, a clôturé à 3 1/16-1/8. Le Comptoir Financier s'est établi à 3 1/4 et sa part à 3. La Banque d'Orient est revenue à 111. Les parts de fondateur de la Société Générale Egyptienne ont fléchi à 35.

Le Crédit Foncier s'est maintenu à 680. La Daira Sanieh a avancé à 14. L'Immobilière a reculé à 365. Les Allotments sont revenus à 2 3/16-1/4. Les Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux ont progressé à 2 1 /8.
Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire ont gagné 8 francs à 188-189. Les parts de fondateur Heliopolis ont été traitées à 9 1/2-10.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich sont restés à 16. Ah Egyptian ont progressé à 5 1/8.
Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land s'est tassée à 2 et les Abdy à 0 5/8. Is1- New Egyptian ont avancé à 16 sh.6.
Le marché des valeurs étant fermé les samedis pendant la saison d'été, le prochain numéro de cette Circulaire ne paraîtra que le lundi ler Juillet 1907.
Nous détachons de notre correspondance d'Alexandrie le passage suivant :

"Les rumeurs de ces jours dernier», suivant lesquelles Sir Ernest Cassel se serait directement intéressé à l'affaire de la Cassa di Sconto, ne sont pu encore confirmées ; tout au contraire, ceux qui les avaient propagées comme certaines se montrent actuellement réservés. En attendant, le travail de vérification entrepris ici se poursuit activement, mais on annonce que, malgré toute la bonne volonté et toute la diligence apportées dans l'examen des comptes, le bilan ne pourra pas être établi avant lundi prochain. D'après le "Phare d'Alexandrie", la dépréciation ne dépasserait pas 15 0/0. Suivant un autre journal, le capital de la Cassa serait intact ; les réserves et les bénéfices seraient seuls compromis. On ajoute que la demande d'un concordat préventif est très probable. Quoi qu'il en soit, on ne tardera pas à être fixé là-dessus, car l'assemblée générale extraordinaire est convoquée, comme vous savez, pour mardi prochain, 2 Juillet 11 ne serait, d'ailleurs, pas impossible quelle fut ajournée si, d'ici là, le bilan n'était pas définitivement dressé."
Le conseil d'administration de l'Aboukir Company Ltd. ti décidé de répartir un dividende intérimaire de 4 0/0, payable à partir du 15 Juillet prochain.

On annonce de Londres l'enregistrement, à la date du 14 Juin courant d'une nouvelle Société anonyme pour l'Egypte sous la dénomination de "Egyptian Oil Trust". Le capital est dc £ 100,000, représenté par autant d'actions à £ 1.
Les membres du premier conseil d'administration ne sont pus encore désignés.
Carnet de l'actionnaire

Les porteurs d'obligation» et d'actions privilégiées de la Société Anonyme du Behéra sont informés que les coujions échéant le 1er Juillet 1907 (coupon No. 26 des obligations et coupon No. 5 des actions privilégiées) seront payés à juirtir delà date susdite an siège de la Société a Alexandrie.

— Il est rappelé aux actionnaires de la H. de Vries and Boutigny Ltd. que le paiement du 3ème quart (5 shellings par action) doit être effectué le 1er Juillet prochain. Les versements doivent être faits aux guichets de la Société, rue Kasr-el-Nil au Caire. Aux termes de 1 article 18 des Statuts, toute somme non payée le jour de son exigibilité porte intérêt de plein droit en faveur de la Société nu taux de 9 0/0 l'an.

— Le coupon No. 6 des actions privilégiées 4 0/0 de l'Agricultural Bank of Egypt et le coupon No. 11 de l'emprunt 4 0/0 de la ville d Alexandrie échéant le 1er Juillet prochain seront payés à partir de cette date à la National Bank of Egypt à Londres.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION

is sold by the principal Chemists throughout the world. Price in England, 2 9 and 4/6.
